awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Control and Analysis of Atomic Few-Body Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding systems of interacting particles is one of the key challenges of physics, and has both fundamental and technological relevance. Such systems generally cannot be fully described in closed analytical form (mathematical expressions that can be written down) for more than two particles, even if their individual properties and the forces between them are precisely known. This dilemma is well-known as the "few-body problem" and it limits the extent to which one can predict the states of the particles (e.g. their positions and velocities) for any time in the future. Therefore, advancing the knowledge of phenomena that emerge due to the complex interplay of several particles requires the joined theoretical and experimental exploration for a wide range of situations. In this project, few-body phenomena of quantum systems consisting of atoms, their electrically charged components (electrons and ions), and photons (the particles of light) will be studied. Such quantum systems represent an ideal testing ground of few-body physics for multiple reasons: First, few-body effects in these systems are ubiquitous and relevant to many research fields and numerous technical applications, particularly in areas such as materials science, quantum chemistry, biological science, and information processing. Second, advanced experimental techniques are available which allow manipulation of the parameters of the few-particle quantum state with a high degree of control and accuracy. Moreover, modern spectrometers enable snapshots to be taken of the state's change over time, allowing details of the state's dynamics to be analyzed. Techniques for the control of atomic few-body systems and for the analysis of their dynamics which have been developed in the past twenty years (largely independently of each other) will be combined in the present project for the first time. This will enable the observation of few-body quantum phenomena while being able to tune the system parameters, and it will allow benchmarking theoretical models.

On a more technical level, this project involves the control and analysis of atomic few-body systems using laser cooling and manipulation techniques to prepare a large variety of initial states, ranging from single excited or polarized lithium atoms to large ensembles of atoms that are cooled to quantum-degeneracy. Systems of only very few atoms can be confined in a micrometer-sized optical dipole trap and their interaction can be tuned close to Feshbach resonances. For the analysis, a "reaction microscope" will be employed allowing the coincident measurements of the momentum vectors of atomic fragments after ionization of the lithium atoms by femtosecond or attosecond laser pulses. In essence, there are three fundamental questions to be addressed in the proposed experiments: First, how do the ionization dynamics depend on the relative orientation (or helicity) of an ionizing laser field and a polarized target atom? Such experiments will help to understand fundamental symmetries and ultimately control the interaction of laser fields with chiral (atomic or molecular) targets, which play a crucial role e.g. in biochemistry. Second, how is the disintegration of an atom due to the interaction with an ionizing field influenced by its environment? This is experimentally only studied for clusters or solid targets, but largely unexplored for more dilute systems. Apart from the fundamental importance of this question, the dependence of the ionization dynamics on the environment is relevant to the understanding of the damage of biological tissue due to radiation. Finally, how does the correlated wave function of a few-particle system change as a function of the particle number and interaction type and strength? The possibility to "engineer" simple few-body systems and observe such systems comprehensively would allow one to "simulate" and understand fundamental quantum phenomena that occur in natural or artificial materials.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant aimed to control and analyze the dynamics of several mutually interacting atomic and sub-atomic particles. On the theoretical side, the underlying challenge is that the equations of motion of these few-body quantum systems cannot be solved in a closed mathematical form - a fact which is well-known as the "Few-Body Problem". Theoretical descriptions rely on simplifications and/or numerical computational methods, and the advancement of our knowledge about few- and many-body phenomena relies on the comparison of these theoretical models with detailed experimental observations. Experimentally, the control and analysis of atomic system is achieved by a combination of several state-of-the-art experimental technologies, including laser cooling, trapping, and manipulation of atoms, generation of ultrashort (femtosecond), intense laser pulses with tailored properties, and high-resolution electron and ion momentum spectroscopy, which enable snapshots to be taken of the quantum state's change over time. The resulting experimental setup is world-wide unique, and it allows to address fundamental questions on light-matter interaction, benchmark theoretical models, and develop and test novel quantum control schemes.

During the CAREER project, three specific scientific question were addressed:

1. Chiral (i.e., handed) objects are not superimposable with their mirror images. There is a large class of molecules that exhibit this fundamental symmetry property, e.g., amino acids and sugar molecules, which occur naturally only in one handedness. Understanding the interaction of such chiral system with circularly polarized light is of key importance to understand the mechanisms that result in the asymmetric distribution of molecules of opposite handedness in biological systems. The difference of the response of chiral objects to the exposure of light of opposite helicity is known as "circular dichroism". In the present project, this phenomenon was experimentally studied for one of the most fundamental chiral atomic systems: A single lithium atom, whose angular momentum is oriented parallel to an ionizing femtosecond laser field. The experiments didn't only reveal a very strong circular dichroism for the few-photon ionization of lithium, it was also shown that the effect can be controlled and even reversed by shifting the frequency of the laser light. Besides its fundamental relevance, it was demonstrated that this system can be used to create spin-polarized electron pulses with a reversible switch on a femtosecond timescale at very high energy resolution, which might find applications, e.g., in new sensing methods of subtle magnetic properties of materials.

2. Wave-particle duality is at the heart of quantum mechanics. It entails that the state of a quantum particle can be described by a wave function. On the one hand, the wave function includes information on probability distributions of, e.g., the positions or momenta of the particles. On the other hand, the wave function contains a "phase angle", which only becomes "visible" if several waves interfere. Measuring and eventually controlling these phase angles is notoriously challenging, but it is key for essentially all emerging quantum technologies. Within this project, experimental schemes were developed and tested which allow to directly extract phase information of the wave functions of ionized electrons. The phase information is obtained by controlling the interference of different ionization pathways. These new measurements do not only provide an extremely sensitive test of theoretical models, but they represent prototype systems for the light-induced quantum control of physical and chemical reaction channels.

3. Quantum systems continuously interact with their environment, which affects the "purity" and coherence of their state. This phenomenon is particularly important for quantum information technology, and it limits, e.g., the time how long a qubit maintains its encoded information. In this CAREER project, the effect of the environment on laser-trapped Rydberg atoms, i.e., highly excited atoms, was investigated. Rydberg atoms are ideal candidates for quantum gates (i.e., basic quantum circuits operating on a small number of qubits) because they exhibit controllable long-range interactions. However, photionization of  Rydberg atoms due to their interaction with the trapping laser field limits the trapping times. Apart of the practical relevance for quantum information technology, the photoionization of Rydberg atoms  is particularly interesting, because it bears the potential to expose violations of the electric-dipole approximation, a theoretical method which is at the heart of the vast amjority of perturbative atomic photoionization studies. Pilot experiments were performed, which pave the way for future studies aiming to induce and analyze exotic (non-dipole) transitions in atom-light interaction.

In summary, the new scientific results advance our understanding of quantum dynamics in the most fundamental atomic few-body systems which are the building blocks of more complex chemical or biological systems. The novel techniques and experimental setups that have been developed provide a unique platform to enhance and test our toolbox of control schemes that can form the basis for next-generation quantum technologies.
